ygData.subject: Re: Colin: Phased Searching Question
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks for the new graph.  I m still a little confused about why the mean structure suddenly plummets at the start of each pruning phase? Wouldn t you expect

Thanks for the new graph.  I'm still a little confused about why the
mean structure suddenly plummets at the start of each pruning phase? 
Wouldn't you expect it to go down gradually as structure is removed
bit by bit?  How could everything instantaneously become less complex
(the way it looks in the graph)?  I'm probably misunderstanding
something..

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> 
> >Colin, my office mate and I were discussing phased vs. blended
> >searching and we were looking at your graphs from your phased
writeup
> >and we realized something about the "Mean Complexity Comparison" is
> >confusing:
> >
> >How many generations pass in 30-50 seconds (the approximate period
of
> >each oscillation)?
> >
> Ah well, the problem here is that each line on the graph is an
average 
> of 3 runs. Therefore the fitness oscillations seen aren't
indicative of 
> the oscillation period during a typical run.
> 
> >  It looks like not enough could be happening in
> >that time to warrant a phase switch.  Does fitness really stagnate
in
> >just 20 or 30 seconds?  We thought maybe you'd expect to see the
first
> >phase of the run stay in the complexifying mode for a long time
before
> >going to pruning, since it doesn't usually stagnate right off the
> >bat?  
> >  
> >
> Ok I'm putting a graph of a single pruning run at:
> 
> http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/pruning_run_1.png
> 
> X-axis is generations in this graph, not clock time.
> 
> This includes the mean complexity (total number of neurons &
connections 
> in a genome) which shows a nice regular oscillation right from the 
> start. The reason why there isn't a long(er) period at the start of
the 
> run (before a pruning phase) is because the threshold for the
pruning 
> phase is set very low. So if you look at the best fitness line where
the 
> first pruning occurs you can see it is flat for a few generations,
and 
> this was enough to trigger the pruning phase. Note that pruning
phase 
> kicks in when mean complexity has risen by some threshold amount
above 
> the level at the end of the last prune run (or the starting mean 
> complexity if no prune phase has occured yet), if this threshold is 
> passed then pruning won't start until the best fitness has stagnated
for 
> some (configurable) number of generations.
> 
> So in the graph you can see that the complexity rises quite steeply
at 
> the start, probably crosses the threshold and then pruning phase
kicks 
> in at the first sign of stagnation in best fitness.
> 
> With regards to the question of how many gens per second and
whether 
> enough time has passed to warrant pruning, remember that the whole 
> experiment runs quite fast, so for example the first pruning phase
in 
> the above graph kicks in at generation 1005 which corresponds to 41
secs 
> clock time. Also you can see that the complexity has risen a lot in
that 
> time and pruning is therefore warranted.
> 
> >I guess the overall question is what is really going on and how is
> >that graph staying so stable?  Maybe it would be useful to see a
graph
> >of *champion* complexity over time, rather than mean.  Then you
might
> >see where pruning was really paying off.
> >  
> >
> Yes that would be worth doing, but don;t discount the pruning of
the 
> population as whole because this speeds up the simulation and
ultimately 
> increases our chances of finding a solution within a given
timeframe. 
> It's an indirect benefit but an important one, I suppose you could
say 
> I'm taking a holistic approach to searching. So rather than just 
> focusing in on how well genomes are doing I also consider how
conducive 
> they are to running a simulation.
> 
> Hope that help clarify things. I still have the raw log files from
all 
> of my experiments so if there are any other questions or if you
want a 
> copy of them, just ask.
> 
> Colin
